com.mozilla.secops.state

Class State

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mozilla.secops.state.State

  • public class State
extends Object
    Represents a generic state interface that can be used to store and load state from or to a persistent storage source

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      State(StateInterface in)
      Construct a new state instance using the specified StateInterface

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void deleteAll()
      Flush all keys in the underlying state storage
      void done()
      Inidicate state object will no longer be used

      Perform simple key fetch operation with no intended follow up modification and update of the value.
      void initialize()
      Initialize state instance

    • Constructor Detail

      • State

        public State(StateInterface in)
        Construct a new state instance using the specified StateInterface
        Parameters:
        in - StateInterface to use for state storage

    • Method Detail

      • deleteAll

        public void deleteAll()
               throws StateException
        Flush all keys in the underlying state storage
        Throws:
        StateException

      • get

        public <T> T get(String s,
                 Class<T> cls)
          throws StateException
        Perform simple key fetch operation with no intended follow up modification and update of the value. For operations involving a fetch, update, and store a new cursor should be allocated by the caller instead.
        Parameters:
        s - State key to fetch state for
        cls - Class to deserialize state data into
        Returns:
        Returns an object containing state data for key, null if not found
        Throws:
        StateException

      • newCursor

        public StateCursor newCursor()
                      throws StateException
        Allocate new state cursor for a set of operations

        In cases where the underlying StateInterface supports transactions, allocating a new cursor will begin a new transaction, from which writes will not take effect until the transaction has been commited.

        If the underlying interface does not support transactions, the new cursor will still provide read and write functionality but it will not provide any form of transaction consistency.

        Returns:
        StateCursor
        Throws:
        StateException

      • initialize

        public void initialize()
                throws StateException
        Initialize state instance

        The initialize function should be called prior to reading or writing any state using the State object.

        Throws:
        StateException

      • done

        public void done()
        Inidicate state object will no longer be used

        The done function must be called to ensure any background threads and resources are released.
